Improvement work has begun on two County Derry roads, with disruption expected to traffic during the completion of the work. The A Glenshane Road, from its junction with the C Knockloughrim Link Road to the A Castledawson Roundabout, will be fully closed to all through traffic on Sunday th February  between the hours of am and pm. This is to allow for necessary road improvement works to be carried out along this stretch of the road. The works are subject to favourable weather conditions and the public will be kept informed of any change. Please see below information on the ersion routes for all through traffic: googletag.cmd.push middot The red line indicates theof the A Glenshane Road which will be closed. middot For those travelling from the North West to Belfast a ersion will be signposted via the C Knockloughrim Link Road and C Hillhead Road to where it meets the main A Hillhead Road. The blue line in the map below indicates this ersion route. middot Those travelling to Magherafelt should also use the above route but take the yellow line in the map below though Castledawson. This ersion will be signposted via the A Moyola Road, A Main Street and the A Magherafelt Road to where it meets the Castledawson Roundabout. googletag.cmd.push middot For those travelling from the East to Derry a ersion will be signposted via the B Castledawson Road, B Church Street, U Union Road, U Hospital Road, B Magherafelt Road, A Tobermore Road and the A Flyover Slip Road to where it meets the A Glenshane Road. The orange line in the map below indicates this ersion route. Magherafelt town traffic should also use this route. Elsewhere, a pound, resurfacing scheme is underway on the Altinure Road, Park. Work is being done in two sections the first section is  metres inand starts close to the junction with the Barnes Road and the second section starts on the approach to the Magherabrack Road junction and extends for some  metres.     The works are scheduled to last for two weeks and will greatly improve the strength and surface quality of the road. To facilitate the works, it will be necessary to operate a road closurebetween the hours of . am and . pm. A two-way ersion is in place via Altinure Road, Glendra Road and Glenshane Road. Access for residents and landowners will be maintained but delays should be expected. The Department has programmed the work operations and traffic management arrangements to minimise inconvenience. However, road users should expect some delays and are advised to allow additional time when travelling in the vicinity of the works and are asked to comply with all temporary traffic restrictions. Improvement work has begun on two County Derry roads, with disruption expected to traffic during the completion of the work. The A Glenshane Road, from its junction with the C Knockloughrim Link Road to the A Castledawson Roundabout, will be fully closed to all through traffic on Sunday th February  between the hours of am and pm. This is to allow for necessary road improvement works to be carried out along this stretch of the road. The works are subject to favourable weather conditions and the public will be kept informed of any change. Please see below information on the ersion routes for all through traffic: googletag.cmd.push middot The red line indicates theof the A Glenshane Road which will be closed. middot For those travelling from the North West to Belfast a ersion will be signposted via the C Knockloughrim Link Road and C Hillhead Road to where it meets the main A Hillhead Road. The blue line in the map below indicates this ersion route. middot Those travelling to Magherafelt should also use the above route but take the yellow line in the map below though Castledawson. This ersion will be signposted via the A Moyola Road, A Main Street and the A Magherafelt Road to where it meets the Castledawson Roundabout. googletag.cmd.push middot For those travelling from the East to Derry a ersion will be signposted via the B Castledawson Road, B Church Street, U Union Road, U Hospital Road, B Magherafelt Road, A Tobermore Road and the A Flyover Slip Road to where it meets the A Glenshane Road. The orange line in the map below indicates this ersion route. Magherafelt town traffic should also use this route. Elsewhere, a pound, resurfacing scheme is underway on the Altinure Road, Park. Work is being done in two sections the first section is  metres inand starts close to the junction with the Barnes Road and the second section starts on the approach to the Magherabrack Road junction and extends for some  metres.     The works are scheduled to last for two weeks and will greatly improve the strength and surface quality of the road. To facilitate the works, it will be necessary to operate a road closurebetween the hours of . am and . pm. A two-way ersion is in place via Altinure Road, Glendra Road and Glenshane Road. Access for residents and landowners will be maintained but delays should be expected. The Department has programmed the work operations and traffic management arrangements to minimise inconvenience. However, road users should expect some delays and are advised to allow additional time when travelling in the vicinity of the works and are asked to comply with all temporary traffic restrictions. Subject to favourable weather conditions, all work will be completed by Friday February  and the Department will keep the public informed of any change.  --If you have a story or want to send a photo or video to us please contact the Derry Now editorial team on    for Derry City stories Or    for County Derry stories. City of Derry Spartan Conor Bradley is the focus of a brand-new documentary film which will be entered into the Cork International Film Festival and the Galway Film Fleadh later this year in the hope of being accepted.Aspiring director and producer EamonKerriganhas spent the last two years filming and documenting the Spartans athlete’s running career so far in Irish athletics.Eamon, alongside a group of talented Derry creatives, is currently putting the finishing touches to the production, entitled ‘It Runs Deep’, a story of passion, dedication and overcoming setbacks in the ultra-competitive world of athletics.Bradley, who ran the  Barcelona Half-Marathon in a time of :, and who starred at the  Morton Games in Dublin, running a spectacular time of : in the m, has been running competitively since he was . He has represented Ireland in multiple events over recent years and has quietly built up a reputation as one of the finest runners to come from the city.Eamon, a runner himself, decided to combine his passion of athletics and cinema, and, taking the skills he has learned working with McMatic Media, has directed and produced his first documentary.It has been a labour of love over the past two years for the -year-old.“Myself and my friend Paul Gormley, who is a producer alongside me on the project, went to Vienna to see Eliud Kipchoge break the two-hour barrier,” he explained.“We were going to make a film about running in general but when we were in Vienna we saw that it wasn’t really what we were looking for, so we talked about it and decided that instead of starting out globally, for our first film we would take it back home and start local.“One of the main characters in the film is Malcolm McCausland who is a real character in the film. We went to his house one night and talked about who we should make the film about. He said Conor was the man because he was a humble guy who has a great story about someone who wanted to represent Ireland internationally. He always showed great potential but once he hit really good form he would get injured, so it was about shining some light on him. The further I got into it, I studied Conor and realised that there was this wealth of archive spread across Ireland.“I rang Conor and asked himhe would be interested in an independent documentary and he said he would, which is where it was conceived.”Eamon’s approach to the film has evolved from that first trip to Vienna and that first conversation with Conor, and whilst the Spartan is the focus, the story is also about Derry itself and the impact of running in Ireland.“When I really honed in on it, I wanted to make the story Derry-based,” Eamon admitted.“The story is just as much about Derry and Ireland as it is about Conor. I started filming with Conor and then the story started to develop.“Conor had that summer when he ran in the Morton Games in Cork and was the fastest guy over m, running sub- which was the first time in  years that someone from Derry did that. He ultimately ends up running in the European Athletics Cross-Country.“Because his story expanded, I was able to follow him and show the European Athletics Association what I was doing.“They could see that I was doing it at a professional level so they allowed me their archive. They gave me unbelievable footage, so the story really expands at the end – it’s not just about Conor.” googletag.cmd.push  Film FestivalsOnce the film is complete, it will be entered into the Cork and Galway Film Festivals in the hope of being accepted.“It’s been quite the journey,” he stated.“It’s just under two years since I started. If it gets traction it might be later this year when we’ll be able to share it. I’m really excited about sharing it online. For me I want to go the professional route. I’ve invested my own money into this. No-one would help us, no-one would back us. It was just an idea.”The entire product is almost exclusively local and Eamon admits he could not have made it this far without a dedicated team.“It is home made,” he emphasises. “The music composed in it is very obvious and prominent and that’s by Composer James Curran. He’s done an unbelievable amount of work and he is someone who people should keep an eye on.“Colm Herron, who is Cameraman and Producer, went to Barcelona with me to film. Caoimhe Sweeney, who has a full other story herself, is a great artist. Her artwork is outstanding.“Jason Bonner also did fabulous work with the animation, while Fiachra OLongain was on nd Camera. There is a wealth of talent in it. The Derry creatives really came together and my friends really helped me bring it to fruition.“I’m just excited about it. We’ve needed a lot of patience during these teams but we’ve just been quietly working away and Conor has been amazing. The whole running community has also been amazing, so many of them have reached out.“When it’s released, I think it will just be a nice piece for the running community and for Conor. He is a really humble guy who doesn’t promote himself. All those nights he was out running, it will just be nice to see that. He has a lot more to come as well.”The challenges brought about by Covid- were unexpected but ultimately manageable for Eamon and his team, and they were finally able to show their work to Conor himself, ahead of the big realse later on this year.“It was scary showing it to Conor because we didn’t show him anything for a year,” Eamon laughed. “Fortunately his reaction was very positive.“Once that happened I could just enjoy it more. On the technical side, I’ve shown some other directors and they have given me good feedback for some tweaks. It’s exciting.“ It’s very much a Derry film and it will be nice to have Conor and Derry on the map for athletics.” googletag.cmd.push  --If you have a story or want to send a photo or video to us please contact the Derry Now editorial team on    for Derry City stories Or    for County Derry stories. title: A life in football well worth it for Andy
story: ANDREW Waterworth has made his mark as one of the best Irish League strikers of his generation.Having started at Kilmore Rec, the  year-old Crossgar hit-man went on to get a taste of the full-time game with a move in  to Hamiliton in the Scottish Premiership after signing from Lisburn Distillery in a pound, deal.Following hishome he joined Glentoran, claiming Irish Cup and Irish Premiership titles during a five-year spell which ended in  when he made the switch to the Glensrsquo great rivals Linfield where he has enjoyed eight trophy-laden years.The Recorder caught up Waterworth to chat about his career, his work away from Linfield, and his hopes and ambitions for his post-playing days.CB: How have you been keeping during lockdown Andrew AW: It has been very strange. I suppose with the first lockdown, things were definitely easier. It was spring, coming into summer, we all had the good weather and there was a novelty to it really. Now though, it has been slightly tougher. But listen, overall I canrsquot complain at all. Irsquom still in training, working in football too, so I am very lucky I have that.CB: How did you find things at the start of lockdown because there did appear to be some ambiguity as to whether the Irish League players could be classed as elite athletes and continue playing  That must have been confusing and unsettling AW: It was a strange one no doubt. Certainly everyone involved in the Irish League, especially at Premiership level, strives to be elite. A lot of us are full-time. I have certainly no problem with the extra training that comes with that and the extra work.But the players do need to be subject to regular testing for Covid-. It is counter-productive to what we, as a society, are trying to do in terms of curtailing this disease otherwise.There has been a lot of ambiguity, but certainly I havenrsquot encountered a player who didnrsquot want to be playing. But obviously we are all concerned that we are able to do so in as safe a manner as possible.At the end of the day, after a match or a training session, we are all going back to loved ones and people who may be vulnerable too. We want to ensure they are as protected as possible.CB: In terms of your role and your standing now at Linfield, you would be considered to be one of the veterans of the side, but you still seem as hungry as ever for goals and success.AW: Absolutely, and in many ways you know that has been the case even more since the first lockdown. At that stage I had so much on with my work with the Irish FA, I probably didnrsquot have the time I would have liked to have dedicated to my own football.But certainly you can see the dference it makes to your season and your ability to hit the ground runningyou do get that good pre-season base in.I was doing my own fitness work in the house during the lockdown.I embrace where I am at now in my career and my age. But I am fortunate in that sense. I know a lot of people who get to my stage and they basically dread retirement. I am  now, so I suppose you do think about when retirement will come.Over the past while, as one of the more senior players at Linfield, I have been able to take on more, I suppose, of that advisory role to younger players. You know those younger guys coming to me asking me about fitness programmes, looking for advice about clubs and things like that, it is great.I am still, believe it or not, learning about the game. I am adapting my role on the pitch too as I move into this latter phase of my playing career. Sometimes you have to do that.But I am going back to foundations and in many ways that has really helped my form this season.Things like learning about playing more with your back to goal, how to use that to your advantage. It is something I have really enjoyed and as I say, embraced.CB: You have played under many of the top managers in the Irish League during your time. David Healy, another local figure at the club like yourself, obviously went into the Linfield job very much managerially as a rookie, although having of course achieved so much as a player. How would you rate him as a manager and indeed how he has made that switch from the pitch to the dugout AW: David I know, never really foresaw becoming a manager. He would tell you that himself. What I do notice about him is, despite everything he achieved, he never talks about his playing days. He is a huge Linfield supporter and he is results-driven. Make no mistake though, he rules with an iron fist.He expects very high standards. It is the job of the players who are there to win. Thatrsquos it, no excuses. Dferent managers bring dferent attributes to any job. But certainly with David,you fall below his standard, you will know.With playing under the like of David Jeffrey, he is a very dferent case. He loved to create that whole ethos of lsquoeverbody hates Linfieldrsquo, and I guess tap into that siege mentality side of things.DJ I suppose, would have been a bit more touchy-feely with the players than perhaps David Healy. Jeffrey would have brought the players to the side, and had the little one-to-one man management conversations with them.But I will say working with David [Healy], especially as he himself was a striker, has taken my game to a whole dferent level since I have been working with him. There is never a comfort zone at Linfield mdash that is the big thing. That has been a key part of my longevity I believe. You constantly have to be kicking on at Linfield. Anyone who coasts at Linfield, they donrsquot last long.CB: Casting your mind back to your days with Kilmore Rec, how much do you think the Amateur League and Kilmore helped you in terms of being ready for the steps up you made AW: Thatrsquos a really good question. The Amateur League is a brilliant springboard for then moving on to the Irish League. You play real first team football. As a player, you can sometimes spend too long at bigger clubsrsquo academies.I had been at the Glentoran academy for a while before I went back to Kilmore for first team football. I was lucky at that time with the Kilmore first team that was there. I played with boys like Gary Curran, Paul Smyth, Joe McMahon.They were players who wanted to win so badly, they played fair, but they played hard. I went into Duck [Donal] Bellrsquos team just as the club were going on a great Irish Cup run that season. That gave me a complete love for the game.But I quickly got to the stage where I didnrsquot just want to do two days a week with my football. Donrsquot get me wrong, the Amateur League, Premier Section is a good standard. As a footballing family, there is a lot for us to be proud of with the Amateur League.Obviously at the moment, all the clubs at that standard are in such a dficult place, but a good club at that level serves a purpose in so many ways, especially for the community. For clubs like Kilmore, and indeed all those playing at that level, it is a real tragedy that there is no football being played at the moment.CB: You are also heavily involved in the coaching side of things with your work with the IFA. Is coaching something you think you might be interested in post-playing, and indeed do you want to remain in football when you hang the boots up AW: I am definitely at the stage now I suppose where I am asking myself how can I remain in the game. It is without doubt something I want to do, to stay in football. But it is about working out exactly in what role that would be best for me.I suppose I have been able to work on a bit of a niche thing for myself with the Irish FA with a coaching and education role. I have done a bit of work with Gerard Lyttle with the Northern Ireland under-age teams and that has been something I have really enjoyed. It is great to see the progress of the younger boys through the dferent age levels with Northern Ireland.CB: You made the move for a time to Hamilton and were up against the top teams in Scotland. How was playing over there for you AW: It is funny you ask about that. My uncle only last night was asking me about all that is happening with Celtic at the moment. When I was there in Scotland you had boys like James McCarthy, Leigh Grfiths, James Forrest all up-and-coming and you could tell easily at that stage that they were boys who were going places. It is definitely a better standard of football in Scotland than a of people realise. I remember when I moved to Hamilton from Lisburn Distillery, I had played for Distillery on the Tuesday night, and then the move to Hamilton picked up momentum quickly.All of a sudden, come the Sunday of that week, there I was playing for Hamilton at Aberdeen in a Scottish Cup game in front of , people. I have to be honest, maybe I was a bit young at the time, maybe the home sickness got the better of me, but I do regret that I came home from Scotland again so soon.I have regretted it every day. You donrsquot want to let the like of that eat away at you, but I was there. I was rubbing shoulders with the gamersquos best.If I could go back and relive that experience again, I would do it in a heartbeat. But you donrsquot want to dwell on it, otherwise it could destroy you.I trained as hard as anyone over there. Maybe I would say compared to others at that standard, I struggled technically. You can get so down on yourself but when you are younger. For me, the chance came too early.It was the last day of the January transfer window when I made the move to Scotland. It actually looked for a long time that Irsquod be going to Aberdeen. However, that fell through at the last minute. I went to Hamilton then, but unfortunately it was just the wrong club for me.I did have chances again to go across the water. When Warren Feeney got the Newport job, he wanted me to go across there, but it wasnrsquot right for me. Everyone has a dferent journey. I was a late developer.Football is a tough place. People watch the Premier League and think that is what it is all about, but in many ways that is not the real picture of what football is, the glamour that is seemingly there. It is so tough to crack the code across the water.It is especially dficult for an Irish kid. If it is an English kid at an English club or a Scottish youngster at a Scottish club, they can easily go back and forth to their family, and alleviate that home-sickness.You canrsquot have thatyou are an Irish kid over there as easily. It can be lonely at times, and it is tough there is no doubt.CB: When you look at Scottish football this season, and particularly in the Premiership for Celtic and Rangers, there has been a complete transformation in fortunes and that in the season when Celtic have been chasing that historic ten-in-a-row. Has the role-reversal between the two Glasgow sides surprised you AW: There is no doubt, the change has been really drastic. I never imagined, despite how much Steven Gerrard has improved Rangers that the gap would be this big, particularly this early in the season.I know Michael Beale, a coach at Rangers from working at the IFA. He is a methodical coach, leaves nothing to chance, and I have no doubt he will have had a big role on the success Rangers are enjoying on the pitch at the moment. Gerrard has done a great job of getting that Rangers back four shored up.But things go wrong. For Celtic, I have no doubt they have found it dficult playing without fans.They definitely feed off the atmosphere that is usually generated by the supporters at Celtic Park.And the Dubai trip has been a really unwanted distraction that has not helped them at all.I do believe however for Celtic it can be a quick turn-around. I donrsquot necessarily see that they will now have to wait years for another Scottish title, the way in which it has been so long since Rangers last won it.Celtic can dust themselves down. Football can be so fluid. That is one of the great things about it..prettyPhoto

title: Ballynahinch named Irish club of the year by writers
story: BALLYNAHINCH RFC have been voted as the best rugby club in Ireland.The club was named Club of the Year by the Guinness Rugby Writers of Ireland Club of the Year.The club won the accolade for its outstanding community outreach work during the Covid- lockdown.This community spirit, said the Rugby writers, was nurtured from mini rugby players through to the seniors.Club chairman James Kirk said everyone at the club was delighted with the award.We are obviously very pleased. We have known about getting the award for a while before it was actually made public knowledge, so it has been in the pipeline, he remarked.ldquoWe are very proud that what it represents especially is our work with community engagement. That is something we pride ourselves on here at Ballynahinch.ldquoIt is really special to have been awarded the prize this year especially. It has been such a tough year, for everyone, and for all sports clubs. It is certainly a nice little boost that we have been able to get this.James said the club was concentrating on getting the green light for action on the pitch to .ldquoThat is what everyone wants and what everyone is missing. To not be able to get playing is dficult, but of course we absolutely recognise why it is the case. Public health is of paramount importance.Ballynahinch RFC usually fields seven adult teams, as well as youth teams, a ladiesrsquo team and a thriving mini rugby section.ldquoThere has been no action at the club since October. New showers, installed at a cost of pound,, have not been used, James explained.He said that before the current lockdown members were able to use their free time to make improvements around the club.ldquoWe obviously donrsquot have that at the moment, due to the current restrictions, he continued.ldquoIt was great to see how the people benefited from it. They certainly did seem to have their spirits lted. Our volunteers are a hugely important part of the club, and that has had to be stopped too.ldquoHopefully things do improve soon, but I guess we are like everyone and just have to wait and see how things develop with coronavirus.Sinead Kissane, chairperson of the Rugby Writers of Ireland, said: ldquo was a very challenging year for all, but it is also important to recognise the work and achievements of many during this dficult time..prettyPhoto

title: Bid for help in the Big Garden Birdwatch event this weekend
story: PEOPLE across the district are being encouraged to take part in the RSPBrsquos annual Big Garden Birdwatch, which takes place this weekend.The UK-wide event is the worldrsquos largest garden wildle survey with locals asked to help from this Friday to Sunday.For many people, garden birds provide an important connection to nature and bring joy and comfort, as well as being vital for mental health and wellbeing, with the RSPB hoping for a big response to the weekend survey.RSPB NI, a charity that works to inspire everyone to give nature a home and to secure a healthy environment for wildle, is hoping that more people than ever will celebrate their love of nature and unite to count garden birds at the end of January for the annual Big Garden Birdwatch.The charity said that over the past year, itrsquos been clear to see how important the natural world is to everyonersquos mental health and wellbeing.In addition, the RSPB says there has been a surge in interest in the nature on peoplersquos doorsteps, with many coming to rely on garden birds to bring joy and comfort in these unsettling times.People keen on taking part in the birdwatch are being asked to spend just one hour watching and recording the birds in their garden before sending their results to the RSPB.Close to half a million people join in the Birdwatch every year across the UK, with just under , of them from Northern Ireland.Anne-Marie McDevitt, the RSPB NIrsquos head of species, said with more people having to stay at home over the past year, everyone has been spending more time outdoors and in gardens and, as a result, have been noticing nature more and having more time to engage with it.ldquoLast year, people were asking usmore birds were singing during the lockdown, but itrsquos not that there has been more wildle about itrsquos just that wersquove had more time and space to notice it, she explained.ldquoBy taking part in the Big Garden Birdwatch, you are helping to build an annual snapshot of how our birdle is doing. It is only by us understanding how our wildle is faring that we can protect it.ldquoWersquove noticed that more people have signed up now for the Birdwatch than had at this stage last year, which is fantastic. We know that nature is in crisis and together we can all take action to solve the problems facing it. Nature needs us.Just one hour every year for the past four decades has made the RSPBrsquos big garden birdwatch the worldrsquos largest garden wildle citizen science project. Now in its nd year,  million birds have been counted.Last yearrsquos results showed that house sparrows remained at the top of the big garden birdwatch rankings in Northern Ireland, with an average of almost five sparrows being spotted in gardens.Collared doves flew into the top , replacing coal tits, while sightings of goldfinches and robins were up too.While counties Down and Tyrone both had the same top two in  mdash house sparrows followed by starlings mdashstarlings were the most-spotted birds in Antrim, Armagh and Derry-Londonderry, ahead of house sparrows, while Fermanaghrsquos number one bird was the chaffinch.The Big Garden Birdwatch continues to highlight the winners and losers in the garden bird world and while house sparrows and starlings may be the UKrsquos most commonly sighted birds, a closer look at the data shows that numbers have ped dramatically since the birdwatch began in .House sparrows are down %, while starlings are down %.Itrsquos also a pattern echoed by two more garden favourites, with blackbirds and robins down % and % respectively.To sign up for the for the big garden birdwatch visit www.rspb.org.uk birdwatch while to learn more about RSPB NIrsquos work log on at www.rspb.org.uk nireland  .prettyPhoto

title: Brexit trading with Great Britain ‘complete nightmare’%2C says owner
story: THE impact of Brexit and the Irish Sea border is impacting on one of the districtrsquos most popular garden centres.Beth Lunney mdash who runs the Saintfield Nursery Centre along with her family mdash has described the impact of the most signicant change to trading in decades and one that will affect many businesses.She said changes became apparent in November, just weeks before the UK formally left the EU.As part of the garden centrersquos preparations for the new sea border it, had signed up to the governmentrsquos Trader Support Service, with Beth also liaising with her suppliers in England.Her longstanding supplier of azaleas and rhododendrons got in touch and revealed that he was not going to be able to get the delivery to Saintfield, explaining that it was because of the possibility that there could be soil in the pots.The UK supplier had correctly interpreted the new rules which apply on trade in plants between Great Britain and Northern Ireland which is still in the EUrsquos plant health system and therefore must apply EU rules on products entering from Great Britain.Plants now need a plant health certicate to enter the country, but some products are completely banned, including soil as it can carry pests and diseases, but there maybe even more problems ahead.Beth said it was being suggested in some quarters that there may be an issue with pallets and even wooden handled forks and spades coming into Northern Ireland due to Brexit and the Irish Sea border and even delays in getting wooden furniture which she currently has on order.In the wake of Bethrsquos UK supplier of azaleas and rhododendrons getting in touch, her rose supplier subsequently got in contact via email to confirm that he would not be able to supply roses which had been on order since the autumn for planned deliveries throughout the season.ldquoThe problem is the peat reduced compost they use along with wood fibre and bark to pot up the roses, Beth explained, expressing sympathy for her suppliers.ldquoThe growers in GB are in a terrible position. They cannot take a chance and send plants to us as they may be delayed at our new border. A plant, like food, is perishable and a delivery could be taken and destroyed. Who will be willing to take that chance  I guess no one.Beth said Northern Ireland has the same climate as the rest of Great Britain and plants that do well there will also do well here, explaining that the local nursery is more selective about taking plants from Europe.She said the new regulations were not just a challenge for Saintfield Nurseries, but the entire Northern Ireland horticultural industry.The new reality for some businesses is that it has become easier to get key supplies from the EU, with Beth explaining that she already gets part of her stock from the Netherlands and the Republic of Ireland and that this may have to increase.She said that several nurseries in the Republic of Ireland are emailing the Saintfield business saying theyrsquore going to have roses, but they may not be the particular ieties that they really want.Beth added: ldquoWe were told we would leave the EU as one country, the UK. We have been badly let down by all those that govern us. We should be equal to Scotland, Wales and England all of us members of the United Kingdom, but sadly now this is not the case.ldquoOne of my suppliers in England who contacted me last Friday thought there would be no problem supplying us but now the whole Northern Ireland and Brexit issue is a complete nightmare.The Horticultural Trades Associationis also lobbying the government, urging it to work with the EU to explore ways to ease the new rules.ldquoThe impact of these complex and burdensome changes is far-reaching for GB and NI, said the organisationrsquos chairman James Barnes, warning that the UKrsquos horticulture industry stands to lose outsolutions cannot be found..prettyPhoto

title: Centennial celebrations event by Spa Wells LOL
story: MEMBERS of Spa Wells LOL  kicked off their year long celebrations of the Centennial of Northern Ireland with a hike up Slieve Croob on New Yearrsquos Day.Crisp clear weather afforded enchanting views stretching to neighbouring Scotland and England.A poem was written to commemorate the occasion.On Slieve Croobrsquos lofty mountain peak:We placed our flag todayTo give a message to the worldThat we are here to stayOne hundred years have come and goneOur motto is the sameThe Union is our safeguardAnd this we will maintain.The members plan more exciting and interestingprojects throughout the year..prettyPhoto

title: Cormac secures place at prestigious Harvard University
story: A TEENAGER will be swapping Downpatrick for Hard University later this year.Cormac Savage is the first pupil from St Patrickrsquos Grammar School to be offered a place at the world famous American university.Seventeen year-old Cormac, who is head boy at St Patrickrsquos, says itrsquos a dream come true to be given an opportunity to study at what is regarded as one of the top universities in the world.Hersquos also grateful to his family and the teachers at St Patrickrsquos, including the principal, Mr Joe McCann, for encouraging him to apply in the first place.Hard is one of the fabled lsquoIvy Leaguersquo universities in the United States and Cormac was one of , students to apply for a place, of which only seven per cent were successful.ldquoWhile Irsquod always wanted to study in the USA, it wasnrsquot until a year ago I seriously considered Hard, he said.ldquoIt was always my dream university but I was convinced I wouldnrsquot get in. It was the support and encouragement from the teachers in St Patrickrsquos who convinced me I should apply.ldquoIrsquom still in disbelief and so grateful to St Patrickrsquos for everything they did to support me.Cormac, who is studying French, Spanish, Politics and English for his A-Levels, leaves for Hard in August.ldquoOne of the things I like most about US universities is that I donrsquot have to declare what Irsquoll major in until my second year, so Irsquoll have freedom to explore in year one, Cormac explained.However, he thinks hersquoll probably end up studying government at the renowned Kennedy School of Government and languages.ldquoHard appeals to me because of the Kennedy School of Government mdash one of the best places to study politics.ldquoThe experience of the professors is immense mdash a lot of them are former politicians and diplomats.ldquoSince being admitted Irsquove been able to see courses I can take and among my possible classes is speechwriting taught by President Obamarsquos former chief speechwriter mdash how incredible.Cormac is deeply interested in politics. He was a member of the UK Youth Parliament for three years and has even rubbed shoulders with new US President Joe Biden.Cormac explains: ldquoI was a massive fan of President Biden long before he launched his campaign. When he visited Ireland in  on his last trip abroad, my then-school principal, Mr Sloan, had heard on the radio hersquod be coming and came to tell me.ldquoI wrote a letter to the Vice President and the embassies in Dublin and Washington and was invited to an event in Dublin Castle where he was the keynote speaker. I got to speak to him for a minute or two and can say he is genuinely the friendly and warm person he seems.ldquoIt was an incredible experience and totally cemented wanting to study in the USA.Cormac added: ldquoWhen Trump won the  election, I knew exactly who would be the  winner and am still very proud about this prediction.ldquoHe was exactly the person America needed to heal the isiveness of the last four years.Cormac added: ldquoIrsquom so grateful for all the teachers and Mr McCann in St Patrickrsquos. The school was absolutely incredible in supporting my application and I know without the schoolrsquos encouragement I wouldnrsquot have even applied, never mind be accepted.ldquoSt Patrickrsquos sent a student to Princeton a couple of years ago but as far as I know, and from what Mr McCann tells me, Irsquom the first to go to Hard..prettyPhoto

title: Eimear seeking payment for student nurses during pandemic
story: A STUDENT nurse from Loughinisland has called on health minister Robin Swann to reconsider his position on paid placements for final year students during the latest coronavirus surge.Eimear Murraywill qualy as a registered nurse in July but says she and her other final year nursing students from Queenrsquos University are being prevented from supporting themselves from part-time jobs in hospitals.She explained while final year students have been told that they still have to go on unpaid placements in hospitals, this is not be the case during the ongoing pandemic for other final year students in the rest of the UK and the Republic of Ireland.Eimear said the fear of cross-contamination from students working in the hospital in part-time roles has led to students feeling ldquofinancially disadvantaged and under-valued.A senior ladies Gaelic footballer with Loughinisland GAC, Eimear has vowed to work aboard and outside the NHS shortly after she qualies as a registered general nurse.ldquoI am annoyed that we are final year students who have to go on placement but have been told we canrsquot work part time because of possible cross contamination, said the student nurse who is due to go on final placement next month to the Ulster Hospital.ldquoThe Department of Health has left us then with no way of earning income and with no other support in place to help us when we are on placement a lot of final year students are ping out.ldquoWhen we have been on placement since the pandemic, we are definitely not supernumerary and are not working in a protected learning environment due to the staff shortages which is shocking, Eimear continued.ldquoIf someone phones in sick, the attitude is that the student is here and we are asked to deal with the patient.Eimear had been working as a part-time agency healthcare assistant in order to supplement her earnings, explaining that she and her colleagues had also been working on Covid wards and the Ulster Hospitalrsquos emergency department on several placements last year, but was only paid for her placement last March.Along with her fellow cohort of  final year students, Eimear had the majority of her written work done and is currently doing two on-line classes a week.ldquoLots of us are feeling very under-valued and fed up, she declared.ldquoI donrsquot see why the Department could not have paid us for the placements and tied us into working two years in the NHS. I have made up my mind to go abroad to work and I think a lot of other students will do that as well.The Nursing and Midwery Council , the registration body for nurses, recently extended its Emergency Standards to allow final year nursing students to undertake paid clinical placements in order to support the existing nursing workforce during the pandemic.While this has been introduced in England, Scotland and Wales, Robin Swann has declined to implement them into Northern Ireland.In early December, the Department of Health said a joint statement from the NMC and UK chief nursing officers explained that students would not be put into paid placements, as happened earlier during the pandemic.The statement said that instead, employing health trusts would protect their status as supernumerary students and continue to support them through high quality placements, which is a fundamental aspect of pre-registration nurse training.South Down MP Chris Hazzard is supporting the call from Eimear and other final year nursing students.He added: ldquoThese nurses are working at the front line and saving lives. Paying them would allow them to be able to support themselves.ldquoI am calling on the health minister to pay these nurses and to also increase the student nurse bursary as a recognition of the fantastic work student nurses are doing in the fight against Covid-..prettyPhoto

title: From the pages of the Down Recorder%2C January 24%2C 2001
story: KILLINCHY ndash The owners of a Killinchy factory, which could close its doors with the loss of  jobs, have this week been accused of playing mind games with staff.Trade union officials and shop stewards are furious with the owners of the Carpets International plant for their continued refusal to come clean about its future.And at a time when staff are unsuretheir jobs are secure, they have been asked by their bosses to increase their weekly productivity.A crucial board meeting planned for Bradford last week to discuss the Killinchy plantrsquos future role was cancelled at the eleventh hour and company officials have been accused of ldquohiding behind a wall of silence.More than  of the staff employed in Killinchy live in Down District and they believe their jobs could be on the line as the plantrsquos American owners press ahead with a major restructuring plan which will result in a number of its factories being downsized and closed.Workers fear the local plant will be axed in a bid to save costs amid claims that the parent company is poundm in debt. Staff are also angry that they will not be told anything about their future for at least another three weeks.BISHOPSCOURT ndash Anyone travelling along Downpatrickrsquos rural roads this week may come across an unlikely road hog.Residents of the Lismore Road, close to Bishopscourt, have been surprised by a foreign visitor taking shelter in their gardens and local country lanes.But this unusual stranger does not pose a threat as the friendly Vietnamese pot-bellied pig has become a favourite with the locals.None of the residents seem to know where he came from but the friendly character, known as lsquoPigrsquo, seems to enjoy pigging around in his new surroundings.One local resident said he feels sorry for his new guest who has taken up lodging in his garden.KILLYLEAGH ndash Work on a near pound, redevelopment scheme at High Street in Killyleagh is due to begin at the end of the month.The ambitious project will provide four new shops, two new apartments and a cottage, helping to transform one of the key areas of the town.Finance for the redevelopment of a number of derelict sites between  and  High Street is being provided by the International Fund for Ireland and the Killyleagh Development Association.Construction work is expected to take around eight months to complete and the project team behind the redevelopment scheme is confident it will greatly enhance an area close to the townrsquos historic castle.It says the style of the new premises will be Georgian to comply with strict conservation and planning requirements. Natural materials will be used with the new premises incorporating traditional design features.BALLYNAHINCH ndash A Ballynahinch man plans to be a genuine Arabian Knight and face the unsparing challenges of the Sahara desert, all in the name of charity.For seven days and seven nights,  year-old Terry MacGowan will run across the hostile and barren land, in stling heat, to raise money for the Northern Ireland Childrenrsquos Hospice.With temperatures soaring to over  degrees celsius, Terry will be expected to cover  miles, including a night marathon, during the testing run which will take place in March.However, the determined  year-old, will be urged on by his son David, who will face the challenges of the desert with his father.DOWNPATRICK ndash Down Council may conduct a district-wide survey to gauge public opinion on a controversial Republican memorial in a Downpatrick park.The councilrsquos most powerful committee wants toadvertisements in newspapers asking for comments on the memorial, which was erected on the spot in Dunleath Park where a police undercover team shot dead top IRA terrorist, Colm Marks, in .The decision by the Policy and Resources Committee to seek public opinion comes as a growing volume of legal opinion indicates the council will eventually have little option but to remove the structure, unless those who built it agree to relocate it themselves.The committeersquos decision must be ratied by the full council before the survey can take place.The council survey is the latest chapter in a long running story which began with the building of the elaborate memorial early last year and which has been the thorniest issue facing councillors for some time.The memorial, which commemorates all IRA members who died in Down District, was constructed without either council or Planning Service permission.Since it went up unionists have wanted it removed, either forcibly by council-employed workmen or by agreement with those who built it. They donrsquot mindit is erected somewhere , just so long as it is not on council-owned land.SAINTFIELD ndash Forty one seasons of flu and hay fever have passed since Dr Jimmy McKelvey first stepped into the shoes of a general practitioner in Saintfield.But an era this week ended when the popular village doctor officially stepped into retirement.Friends and former colleagues of the local practitioner came together last Tuesday evening at the local Guildhall to wish him well in his retirement.The well-wishers were also there to officially thank Dr McKelveyrsquos we, Dr Moira Hopkins, for her service to the local community.CASTLEWELLAN ndash A Castlewellan man saved his nephewrsquos le last week after the three-month old baby stopped breathing.Ciaran Buistrsquos tiny heart stopped as he slept in his St Paulrsquos Close home, but he was resuscitated and brought back to le by his uncle moments before paramedics arrived at the family home.Sharon and Fergus McCartan were baby-sitting their nephew at the time of the incident and have spoken publicly about what they have described as their ldquofrantic  minutes before the paramedics arrived.Sharon, who regularly looks after her sisterrsquos baby, said she would always check on Ciaran more than she would her own children.Speaking after last weekrsquos nightmare event, she revealed her husband asked why she had not wakened Ciaran and brought him downstairs and explained he went up to check the baby and found that he had turned blue.STRANGFORD ndash Work is to begin over the next few weeks on the planting of a small woodland in Strangford.After months of planning, the planting of the woodland and construction of scenic walkways in the Old Court Estate are due to commence early next month.New paths, and upgrading of some footpaths, will link Strangford village from Squeeze Gut, over Compass Hill, past the old Tea House, down to Pond Wood and along the shore of Strangford Lough.Restoration of the old Japanese garden pond at the foot of Compass Hill is planned to encourage the growth of natural habitat for a range of birds, animals and plant s.CARRYDUFF ndash A Carryduff woman is preparing to set off on a trek through the worldrsquos oldest desert ndash but it will certainly be no holly-day.For Donna Holly will be enduring searing temperatures of over  degrees celsius as she takes part in the seven-day,  kilometre-long trek through the Namib Desert in Namibia in aid of the Mencap charity.Donna, who only heard about the fundraising journey while listening to the radio last August, has spent the last four months training and raising funds for the arduous hike, which will begin in the early hours of February .In addition to the demanding training,  year-old Donna had to raise a minimum of pound, to take part in the trek, but has surpassed this amount and has raised over pound, through ious events with funding still coming in from local people..prettyPhoto

title: Jim a key figure in local table tennis
story: GROWING up in Strangford, close to the old Stella Maris Hall, it was always likely that Jim Ritchie would join the table tennis club so long associated with bringing on young players thanks to Leslie Sullivan mdash still known to this day as the lsquoSullivan Babesrsquo.The club, now the longest-serving in the Lecale Table Tennis League, not only produced Jim but also former stars Harry Dougherty, Mickey Swail, Raymond Shields and, perhaps the best known of all and still current number one, Joe lsquoRollerrsquo McConville.Jim remains associated with Strangford, despite living for many years in Castlewellan. He has performed the role of club chairman, with his playing reduced to part-time due to the fact he suffers from arthritis in a finger.He has played for Drumaroad in the past, and in more recent seasons for the former top club in Downpatrick, De La Salle.Back in the days of the Lecale Leaguersquos Spin magazine, which was edited by the late and sadly-missed Gerry Carson, Jim provided lsquoPeople in the Newsrsquo and lsquoAt your Servicersquo on a regular basis.This was back in the late s. Starting in  he produced another magazine named Equipment Plus.At this stage, he was running his Table Tennis Servicesfrom his home in Castlewellan. However, as many will recall, for some years he ran Northern Irelandrsquos only table tennis shop in Irish Street, Downpatrick. He had a steady line of customers from near and far who came to make their purchases.As all local players will of course know, Jim is the local man to go to for advice on what rubber suits inidual players.As one who has made use of his help and advice on many occasions, it is quite common to arrive in Strangford to play a match, or indeed in another local hall, and find Jim replacing rubbers.He has also given people from ious local halls advice and has moved many on to pimpled rubbers in recent years, saving them money. A good many seasons back, Jim, anxious to give some of the Strangford clubrsquos younger players a bit of extra publicity, wrote reports for the Down Recorder.As a close associate to the long-time secretary of the Lecale League, Pat Morgan, there was never any doubt who would replace Pat when he sadly passed away.Since taking over, he has certainly done his utmost to keep the league going. He has brought in new clubs and written regular and well-received reports, as well as travelling to matches to take team photos.As well as being a great supporter of the Lecale League over many years, he has also been a great supporter of the East Down Churches League.He has attended and made donations for the leaguersquos annual charity cup match, as well as being present at their annual presentation evening.While Jim has been in regular action in recent seasons, he has proven that while form is temporary, class is permanent.When called upon to help a local team out in the Belfast  District League, he has been the only player on the team to win a game.As well as being a title-winning player, he has also proven he is a superb organiser as those that have attended the Lecale Leaguersquos th and th anniversary evenings know.In fact, so many turned up at the th anniversary event that lsquohouse fullrsquo notices had to go up.He even ran out of anniversary mugs for those who had played in the league over the years.While the Lecale League may not have as many teams as it did had in the past, the fact that it is still going is mainly thanks to Jim.It is also worth noting that with his guidance, the many charity tournaments he runs every season have raised a lot of money for Marie Curie and provided some great action for players.It is thanks to Jim and the late Pat Morgan that the league has been going now for over  years. Herersquos hoping Jim will keep it going for many more to come when the current pandemic passes..prettyPhoto

title: PIPS Downpatrick closes its doors after 16 years’ service
story: A LOCAL suicide prevention group started by a grieving Killough mother  years ago has closed its doors for good.The McAteer family, who were behind PIPS Downpatrick, have stepped down from running the group which is credited with saving many lives locally.They received hundreds of thank-up messages from iniduals and families they have helped after they announced the news on social media.Josephine McAteer started PIPS Downpatrick after her  year-old son Gerard took his own le after a night out in .She later described his loss like ldquobeing under water and ldquohell and spoke of how she had to wait eight months for grief counselling while having to deal with the stigma of how her son died.Determined to improve the local support to families like hers, Josephine was inspired by another bereaved parent, Philip McTaggart who founded PIPS Belfast, to get the group up and running.She was often one of first early callers to a familyrsquos door after they had lost a family member and offered direct help to parents whose children where going through a crisis.Mrs McAteer was joined later by her daughter Brenda, son Patrick and daughter-in-law Andrea who were all heavily involved in the group as well as managing fund-raising activities.The family suffered another sad loss six years after Gerardrsquos death when his brother Michael died from a brain tumour at the age of .PIPS Downpatrick funded counsellors and therapists to provide talk therapy as well as suicide awareness training and holistic therapies, mentoring and mediation classes.The group were often able to provide one to one counselling quickly and became a collective voice for families left traumatised by the loss of their loved ones.Brenda explained the reasoning behind the emotional reason to close.ldquoWe set out to highlight suicide and the stigma around it and we do feel we have done a good job, she said.ldquoIt was always going to come to an end and we never thought we would last this long. Even before the pandemic hit last year, wersquod got to a point where we were considering closing. Then the pandemic happened and we knew that it wasnrsquot the right time. We just had to keep going.ldquoAfter Christmas we knew we all needed to have time for ourselves and our families as we realised that so much of our own lives were being out on hold doing the voluntary work. Mum is also getting older, shersquos  now, and we just felt that we had done as much as we could.She stressed that all counselling sessions promised would continue they were complete.ldquoWe have been family run on a voluntary basis and due to the generosity of the local community, we were able to pay up to three therapists at any given time with no waiting time for those in distress or despair, added Brenda.She said that while the lockdown had presented challenges to the group regarding fund-raising and provision of support, counselling work continued through Zoom.ldquoTherersquos been some great fund-raising and we have been truly grateful but we just felt it was time to step back.Brenda said that while she hope that others may well organise and take over the gap that PIPS Downpatrickrsquos closure may leave, she felt that local mental health provision had moved on since the group started.ldquoWe would hope that the statutory services run by the Trust will continue. There are now mental health social workers in all the surgeries, yet  years ago you wouldnrsquot have heard of this, she added.Brenda said that while her family was sad at the closure, they were all very proud of what they had achieved with the help of the local community.ldquoWe truly believe we have saved lives and while it has been challenging at times, I wouldnrsquot have missed it for the world. I met such wonderful people and we would like to thank everyone who worked with us and supported us.A helpful leaflet called The Art of Conversation on how to talk to a person feeling potentially suicidal is available from local group Suicide Down to Zero..prettyPhoto

title: Running changes in 2021
story: A SPORTING activity which seems to have developed a bit of a boom in these days of winter lockdown in the midst of the spread of coronavirus is running.With team action below elite level being halted in every sport, and gyms being forced to shut, many people around Down District have taken to pounding the roads for a run, either by themselves, or within their bubble.Whilst current regulations are strict, as long as the running is within that bubble, socially-distanced, and in the runnerrsquos own locality, then it is proving to be a very beneficial outlet for many who are enjoying the activity.Alison Carroll, who is a committee member with East Down Athletics Club, said that she has definitely noticed more people around Down District pounding the pavements.ldquoRunning outside on onersquos own, is recognised by people as being low-risk in terms of the potential for the spread of covid-, she said.ldquoI think even before they were shut, people perhaps became a bit more unsure about using gyms, but still wanted to maintain their fitness and that is where running came in for many of them.Data recently released by the mile-tracking app Strava has shown just how people have reacted to the pandemic. In , the  gained two million new members worldwide per month.The Strava team wrote in the report: ldquoAt the global level, the Covid- pandemic resulted in a rise of activity on Strava like wersquove never seen before, far surpassing our normal projections.In the UK, from March to May, members logged  per cent more outdoor activities than would be expected for that time of year, making the UK the most active global nation for outdoor activity.Alison continued: ldquoIt was a very bad year for everyone last year, and unfortunately this year has started in much the same way. With running though, it is one of those sports that is still accessible to us to take part in.When the regulations on sporting activity took hold, Alison said she and other members of the club were fastidious in following them to the letter.ldquoWe took our directive closely from Sport NI. We were able to develop a training plan that our members could follow inidually in January, and our members, because of the fact they are associated with the club, are particularly stringent about following the protocols as they should be done.ldquoRunning is something that can still be done outside, safely, and at a distance. Unless, for example you are running in a train of people, in these times, it is still a relatively low-risk activity. Both our sport and cycling have been able to proceed relatively well in terms of participation numbers.ldquoAnd from a mental health perspective, it offers so much. It has been a terrible time, for everybody for months with everything that has been happening. People have lost their lives, their loved ones, their livelihoods, running can be a nice outlet to just get away from things for that short time.Things may still be in limbo now in terms of planning any sporting activities locally in the district, but East Down AC members are still keeping their fingers crossed that the year ahead can still be one which will become more positive the longer into it we get.ldquoThis time last year, we would have had all our members training a lot, said Alison. ldquoThis year of course, we are not able to offer that. The Jimmyrsquos K is obviously a big event traditionally in the local athletics calendar, but that can attract around  runners. At the moment, it is just too dicy to even entertain that we could host that.ldquoHowever, we havenrsquot given up hope that we can still have some action to speak of later in the year with events. We would urge our members to keep training, keep themselves ready for when things can come back.ldquoWe know there are people out there who are naturally struggling with how things are. However people are there for you. The amount of virtual contact we all now have is something to embrace in these times. We have found we can even run a virtual league, which is something.Alison is hopeful that normal service can be resumed soon, as for many it is a huge leline to be a member of a running club.ldquoSome people are solitary. They may live alone, or work long hours alone. For those people, coming to the club to train, is as important in terms of getting face-to-face company with others.ldquoThese are the type of runners who donrsquot come to win the medals, they donrsquot come with winning as being the most important thing. It is about that human connection.ldquoDefinitely when I look around the town in Downpatrick, I can see more people out running, especially around the Quoile River and on the streets.ldquoRunning is a great outlet. It is not expensive, and for members of our club in particular, without it they would all be a lot more lonely..prettyPhoto

title: Schools set for closure to pave way for merger
story: A PLAN to open a new co-educational voluntary grammar school for , pupils in Downpatrick from September  has been announced by the Education Authority.A two-month public consultation began today, with the final decision to be taken by Education Minister Peter Weir.Under the proposal St Patrickrsquos Grammar School would merge with St Maryrsquos High School and De La Salle High School.Adverts announcing the proposed dates of closure for all three schools and the opening of the new school have been placed by the Education Authority in todayrsquos Recorder.The Board of Governors at St Patrickrsquos are opposed to the merger and have reaffirmed their opposition this week, while De La Salle and St Maryrsquos are both in favour of the controversial plan going ahead.In a statement issued last night the Board of Governors at St Patrickrsquos called on parents, past pupils and members of the public to make their views known over the next two months.They said: ldquoThe outcome of this consultation will have a lasting impact, not just in the school, with staff and pupils, but its ramications will be felt throughout the local community in East Down.ldquoThe Board of Governors and management do not believe the case has been made for the proposals as currently outlined and will be re-stating the reasons for this as part of the public consultation process. That said, the Board and management are focused on achieving the best outcomes for all concerned.ldquoThe Board and management ask the parents of pupils, past pupils and members of the public impacted by these proposals to make their voices heard by participating in the consultation process. This is a matter for the entire community ndash not just those directly involved in education.The statement continued: ldquoFor over  years, St Patrickrsquos [the Red High] has been at the heart of the local community as a centre of learning, a resource hub and as an active contributor to civic le.ldquoPupils, past and present, have made and continue to make signicant contributions in the fields of sport, art, music, business and public service.ldquoThe motivation of the Board of Governors and management of the school is to ensure the widest range of parental and pupil choice remains available in the East Down region.Last December, the chairman of the Board of Governors, Dr Aidan Hamill, lost an application to the High Court for a judicial review questioning the Department of Educationrsquos authority to go ahead with the proposal before securing agreement from its governors.Under the merger plan the new school would educate girls and boys aged - with an admission of  pupils per year, with up to a maximum of % of pupils admitted through academic selection.Grammar schools in Northern Ireland normally admit students exclusively through academic selection.It is intended that existing school campuses would be used ldquopending capital investment for a one site solution.The closure of the three schools will also mean the loss of distinctive local school unorms as well as requiring all teaching and support staff to reapply for jobs at the proposed new school.The controversial amalgamation has been put forward by the Council for Catholic Maintained Schoolson behalf of the De La Salle Congregation, who are the trustees of all three schools.St Maryrsquos High School and De La Salle High School have declined to comment this week.However, both schools previously welcomed the proposed amalgamation, which originally included merging St Columbarsquos College in Portaferry.Mr Ciaran Maguire, principal of De La Salle, said in December that he was ldquodelighted to see the proposal going to full public consultation.He said at the time: ldquoItrsquos been a long time coming. I am reassured now that the families of the greater Downpatrick area will have an opportunity to finally get behind the vision to secure the town as a model of good practice, where childrenrsquos education is a priority.Ms Rosemary McLaughlin, principal of St Maryrsquos, said last September that the merger reflected her values and belief in all-ability schools.She said: ldquoIn terms of social justice, I feel the move is very important. In an all-ability school you can cater for the gted and talented but you can also support children who need it..prettyPhoto

title: Search is on to find talent for St Patrick Centre show
story: MUSICIANS, dancers and storytellers are being invited to virtual auditions for an innovative new show recounting the story of St Patrick.The contemporary show is being designed for dinner-theatre experiences at the St Patrick Centre in Downpatrick and for international festivals post-lockdown.The centre is presenting the experience in partnership with Verdant Productions and celebrity chef Terry McCoy, creator of St Patrickrsquos Plate.Award-winning producer Donal Shiels, founder of Verdant Productions and director choreographer Belinda Murphy mdash an assistant choreographer on the original Riverdance mdash have now launched virtual auditions to create the hour-long show.ldquoThis is great news for the arts sector especially for traditional dancers and singers and storytellers, said Dr Tim Campbell, Director of the St Patrick Centre.ldquoCovid has wreaked havoc with the arts sector and we think this show will provide much-needed income for artists while showcasing the amazing story of Patrick.ldquoAudiences will be able to enjoy the story of Patrick mdash which is also the story of Ireland mdash in all its rich beauty, history and heritage.Mr Shiels is particularly seeking the best artists from the Co Down area, where Saint Patrick arrived in AD.ldquoI certainly wasnrsquot aware of how embedded St Patrick was in the Downpatrick locality and that intrigued me and in a sense we are going to the source of where St Patrick started his journey, he said.ldquoMusic, dance, theatre and design will form the bedrock of our production. Technology will be used to provide a back of iconic locations such as Slieve Patrick, the Rock of Cashel, the Giantrsquos Causeway and Slemish Mountain. This is a musical and visual tale of ancient times that is relevant and attractive to modern Ireland.The St Patrick Show will also feature spoken word from  Grammy-nominated Fontaines DC frontman Grian Chatten and other well-known artists.The show will be filmed and be available virtually at first, but has the potential to create a new dinner-theatre culture at the St Patrick Centre and to travel internationally.ldquoWe already have interest from New York and Washington for this exciting project, said Dr Campbell. ldquoWe had planned four shows during St Patrickrsquos Week at the St Patrick Centre, but now due to Covid Restrictions this will be a virtual online event.It is anticipated that rehearsals will begin next month, subject government restrictions, with filming dates in early March.When restrictions lt, dinner theatre audiences in Downpatrick will not only drink in the refreshing story of Patrick this summer, but taste unique recipes created by celebrity chef Terry McCoyrsquos, showcased in his book, Saint Patrickrsquos Plate.Funding has come from from the Arts Council, the Community Foundation for Northern Ireland and Newry Mourne and Down Council.The aim is to have the show in place, marketed and ready for theof the tourism season.The St Patrick Centre is currently in discussion with Tourism Ireland about releasing the virtual event in tourist markets around the world, particularly in the United States.Details can be found on the St Patrick Centrersquos website: www.saintpatrickcentre.Artists are being asked to submit their CVs and tapes via email at stpatrickcentreshow@gmail.prettyPhoto

title: Speeder clocked at 82mph – double road speed limit
story: A DRIVER has been clocked travelling at mph in the mph zone at the Strangford Road in Downpatrick.The figure mdash confirmed by the districtrsquos Policing and Community Safety Partnership mdash was recorded on an electronic speed indicator device which was one of a number put in place across the district last year.While the provision of the device at the entrance to a sports pitch at the Strangford Road was welcomed, a number of residents believe that the device should be located further back long the main road as the speed of drivers along this particularly busy and built-up area is a major concern.Some Strangford Road residents argue that the problem with the speeding device is that it is in the wrong location, given that it is just a few hundred yards from the start of a mph zone close to the townrsquos war memorial.They say that effectively, the speed restriction sign is policing only small section of the busy main road where there are literally just a handful of homes.Further back along the road, there are several major housing developments, many where young families live. There is also a busy local authority garage and depot and a private care nursing home, with this section of road governed by a mph limit.Residents say that the overwhelming majority of drivers who speed along the road are travelling from the Strangford direction and that the issue could be addressed mdashthe speed indicator sign was relocated further back to the entrance to Lecale Park mdashit has to have any signicant impact on the speeding.Those who live at this part of Downpatrick say while the majority of drivers obey the mph speed limit, there are a number who do not.The new speed indicator devices, designed to make drivers aware of their speed and to slow down, are dotted across the Newry, Mourne and Down Council area and have been warmly welcomed.South Down MLA Colin McGrath and Downpatrick councillor John Trainor say the speeding data recorded by the devices and released by the Policing and Community and Safety Partnershipshows an average speed reduction in the Downpatrick area of .% and that the new initiative is working.Mr McGrath said that when he and his SDLP colleague initially floated the idea of erecting the speed indicator signs, the feedback was that the such a scheme would not be efficient and would be too expensive, with little reward.He insists that confirmation that in the Downpatrick area alone speeds have reduced by .% in the short time the devices have been in place vindicates their installation.ldquoWhile John and I are delighted to hear that speeds are reducing across the district, we are in no way complacent about this.ldquoThe fact that the PCSP is doubling the provision of speed indicator signs is not only an indication of their efficacy, but also highlights the continued need for them.However, Mr McGrath said he was concerned about the mph speed recorded at the Strangford Road and appealed to all drivers to ensure they stick to the speed limit.Cllr Trainor said plans were in place to provide an additional seven speed indicator devices across the district.He added: ldquoCombining this with infrastructure minister Nichola Mallonrsquos scheme for mph zones at  schools across the country can only help safety on our roads.ldquoConsidering the very low temperatures we have witnessed this weekend, this is another reminder that we all need to be conscious of our speed..prettyPhoto

title: St Patrick’s parade off
story: NEWRY, Mourne and Down Council has pulled the plug on the forthcoming St Patrickrsquos Day parade in Downpatrick.The decision mdash confirmed on Monday mdash comes a week after a number of councillors urged the local authority to formally cancel the cross-community event due to the continuing coronavirus pandemic.Last yearrsquos cross-community spectacular was cancelled ahead of the first national lockdown to help combat the deadly virus and with infection rates remaining high across the district, the council has finally decided to cancel the event in the grip of the continuing public health emergency.The local authority, which last week would only confirm that it was ldquoreviewing plans for its St Patrickrsquos Day events in line with the current restrictions and ongoing response to the Covid pandemic, told councillors on Monday afternoon that the Downpatrick parade and one in Newry had been postponed, with the wider media informed yesterday.In the wake of other councils postponing their respective St Patrickrsquos Day parades, Newry, Mourne and Down was coming under increasing pressure to follow suit.The local parades have now been added to the growing list of national and international events across Northern Ireland which have been cancelled due to the pandemic, including the North West  motorcycle races.Belfast City Council has cancelled its St Patrickrsquos Day parade, with Derry City and Strabane and Armagh City, Banbridge and Craigavon councils currently discussing how their March  events will be celebrated.Local council officials have confirmed that following careful consideration of the current restrictions and the ongoing response to the Covid- pandemic, they have ldquoregretfully cancelled the traditional St Patrickrsquos Day celebrations.The organisation has confirmed that it will be hosting some activities and performances online via its tourism and arts social media channels.In addition, training green spotlights on a number of major buildings, including Down Cathedral and St Patrickrsquos Church in Downpatrick, is expected to go ahead as planned,restrictions allow.Council chairwoman Laura Devlin said it was with ldquogreat regret that the annual St Patrickrsquos Day parades have been cancelled for the second year in a row.She said the March  events were normally an opportunity to celebrate the districtrsquos connection with St Patrick and the arearsquos important place in his the patron saintrsquos story.ldquoI know how disappointed many will be about this decision and I share their disappointment, said Cllr Devlin. ldquoHowever, the councilrsquos priority at this time is to continue to support the ongoing response to the Covid- pandemic across wider society.She said that the decision to cancel was made in the best interests of residents, visitors, festival participants and event partners.She also confirmed that the local authority will continue to review plans for this yearrsquos tourism events programme on an ongoing basis and in line with guidance from the Northern Ireland Executive.Councillors Willie Clarke, Dermot Curran, Billy Walker and Robert Burgess, who last week appealed to the local council to cancel the parade, welcomed the decision and said they were looking forward to the  event going ahead.They said the local authority had to act to avoid any needless delay, warning that there was no way any festival parade could take place in the current Covid climate.Cllr Clarke said people needed to know that the parade would not happen, highlighting the continuing importance of protecting peoplersquos health.Cllr Curran said the event could not possibly have proceeded, given the ongoing public health emergency.He said the Covid situation remained ldquoextremely serious and that news of the parade cancellation would not come as a surprise.Cllr Walker urged council officials not to wait until the ldquoeleventh hour to pull the plug on the parade and hoped that next yearrsquos event will be one of the best ever.Cllr Burgess said current public health advice was clear, which meant the local council had no option but to cancel the parade, and urged council officials to start preparations for next yearrsquos event..prettyPhoto

title: Views sought on play park upgrade
story: NEWCASTLE residents are being encouraged to have their say on plans to upgrade the hugely popular Downs Road play park.Newry, Mourne and Down Council mdash which is planning to carry out the work mdash wants to hear what local people have to say about the proposal.Confirmation that residents are being asked for their views has been welcomed by Mournes councillor, Willie Clarke, who is delighted the play facility is to be upgraded.ldquoI have been campaigning for several years for the current play equipment to be upgraded, he said, revealing that he persuaded the council to use resources initially earmarked for enhancing play equipment at the Newcastle Centre to be invested at the Downs Road.ldquoGiven that the local authority is surveying what people would like to see provided, it is essential that they respond.Cllr Clarke hopes people will engage in the consultation process, emphasising the need toensure that all-ability equipment will feature in the upgraded play park to cater for children with special needs.He added: ldquoThe views and opinions of children, young people and communities are highly important to the local council and will provide the organisation with an opportunity to actively participate in the process of improving play experiences..prettyPhoto
